PRESIDENT GORDON

By TED ROHRLICH
President Lincoln Gordon's announcement of
a set of proposed guidelines for student conduct
has triggered a quiet protest from students,
faculty, and administration officials involved in
formulating the proposed policy.
Gordon's announcement came at an
orientation assembly of freshmen and their
families in Shriver Hall last Wednesday at which
the President outlined the three broad areas of
student behavior subject to University sanction.
"1. Conduct that abridges the rights and
interests of others, especially as it affects
•t heir educational goals within the
University or threatens their safety, health,
welfare or property.
"2. Conduct that disrupts the normal
functioning of the University or that
damages physical facilities of the
University.
"3. Conduct that significantly impairs the
effective relationship of the University to
the larger community of which it is a part."
In an indirect reply to Dr. Gordon's speech,
Student Council President John Guess
emphasized that universities have no right
to restrict a student's "personal" activities
outside the university.
In November, 1968, Gordon appointed a
university-wide ad hoc committee "to consider
the preparation of a draft statement on student
conduct appropriate for application on a
University-wide basis."
Significance Differences?
On May 29, when the committee reported
back, the President, modified the committee's
recommendations and sent his own proposals for
the Deans of the four divisions of the University

to consider.
Allyn W. Kimball, Dean of the Faculty of
Arts and Sciences, has referred the President's
suggestions to the .Committee on Student Affairs
for further action.
When asked why an ad hOc committee
composed of members of the Faculty of Arts
and Sciences, was appointed to consider a
University-wide disciplinary policy, Dean
Kimball replied that Dr. Bevan 'personified the
other divisions of the University.
Kimball stated earlier that Gordon had found
it necessary to appoint a special committee
rather than tap the Committee on Student
Affair's, since the latter was strictly a Homewood
group.
No statement was offered to explain how the
ad hoc committee difered significantly from the
Committee on Student Affairs. Both are
composed of Arts and Sciences members.
Bad Faith
Bill Betcher. an undergraduate member of the
ad hoc committee, asserted that Dr. Gordon
"acted in bad faith" by revising the committee's
recommendations during the summer.
Betcher pointed out that the President had
"numerous opportunities" to comment on the
committee's work in its developmental stages.
Instead, Gordon chose to wait until the final
draft had been completed to overhaul the
committee's proposals.
The ad hoc committee report and Dr.
Gordon's revisions called for an appeals board to
review disciplinary actions taken by the Director
of Student Affairs or the University President.

As unexpected change in the .number of
summer rejections has boosted this year's
freshman class to an all time high of five

by DAVID S. HOELSCHER
News Director
Several weeks ago, the President of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital, Dr. Russell
A. Nelson, stated that moves towards
unionization of the non-professional
Hospital employees "is not in the best
interests of the public, patients
or ...employees" and may lead to a
$20-a-day increase in present hospital
rates. Last week Local 1199E of the
Hospital and Nursing Home Employees
Union won the right to represent
Hospital employees in
Labor/management negotiations.
The immediate effect of the
unionization of the Hospital will
remain unclear until the negotiations
between union and Hospital officials
have been completed. Nevertheless,
Nelson did indicate significant
misgivings over the union's success.
In a letter to all hospital employees
Dr. Nelson states that"by winning the
right to represent these
employees ... the union has assumed
tremendous responsibilities.
"During the campaign the union
made many promises that concern us
and concern us now." He said that it is
"greatly difficult, if not impossible" for
the hospital to meet these promises.
Primary concern of the hospital
administration rests with the union's
demand for $100 minimum weekly
salary ($2.50 per hour). At present, the
minimum wage at the hospital is $1.80
per hour, 35 cents above the
Federalminimum wage for hospital
workers.
Necessary Updating
Nelson admitted that the present
minimum level at Hopkins is low, but

noted that the hospital has committed
itself to raising that wage. He did not
specify the amount of the proposed
increase or when such a re-evaluation
would by conducted, however.
Paul J. Van Nevel, chief public
relations officer for Hopkins, also
warned against the sudden cost increase
resulting from the demands. It would lie
argues, lead "to a ripple effect resulting
in a raise that could not be borne by the
hospital, while affecting many other
segments of society."
"The hospital's reaction," countered
Fred Punch, chief organizer of 1199E,
"is typical of any other profiteer.
Rather than reduce profits he would
visit the added expense on those who
can least afford it - - the patients."
Other union demands include an end
to forced retirement, free life insurance,
free hospitalization and respect for
seniority.
Nelson stated that despite past
difficulties, he hoped "differences can
be resolved in fair bargaining between
union and hospital representatives. We
hope, too, that the union will place the
public interest predominently among its
objectives, as the hospital does."
Punch echoed Nelson's statement:
"Our issues are firm but we will enter all
negotiations in the true spirit of
collective bargaining."
When asked about union policy for
the future, Punch replied, however,"We
cannot negotiate on the media, our
position is clear."
The major portion of Local 1199E's
campaign for unionization of all
non-professional hospital employees
began over the summer months. In
mid-August the union won elections
similar to last week's Hopkins election,
at Lutheran Hospital and Mt. Sinai
Hospital.

JHU Fights Non-Ivy Image
In an attempt to reverse the position
of Hopkins as a second choice school
for those who were rejected by the Ivy
League, the - Homewood Admissions
Office has announced a widespread
reorganization of its alumni associations
involved in recruitment.
Although local Hopkins Alumni
Associations have been assisting in the
undergraduate recruiting process for the
past fifteen years, they have been acting
as isolated groups with no national
co-ordination. The new National
Alumni Schools Committee,-headed by
the Hon. Robert I. H. Hammerman of
Baltimore's Supreme Bench, will serve
as an overseeing and co-ordinating body.
The overall objectives of the Committee
will be to "organize Johns Hopkins
alumni in each state in the nation," he
said, and Special emphasis will be placed
on regions like the far west, where the
University generally attracts fewer
applicants.
The Committee will be aided by
Assistant Director of Admissions
Michael Anderson, who will help with
the organization as well as providing the
local committees with access to the
necessary Admissions Office reports and
records. Mr. Anderson noted a number
of reasons for the reorganization.
Primarily the University wants to
maintain its national prestige by
continuing to draw students from all
parts of the country. Mr. Anderson
expressed the long term goal as "having
every school in the country" available
to the Committee. Short term plans are
to cover "every major city and every
state."
Youthful Image
The need for Alumni assistance arises
from the inability of the small
Admissions Office staff to adequately
cover all the possible applicants. The
intense competion from other schools
makes it necessary to search out talent
wherever it appears, explained
Anderson. The Alumni Committee will
act in this area, seeking out qualified
students and.generating applications to.

Hopkins.
The national organization will
appoint a chairman for each local group.
These will then choose their own local
committees. Although there are no
strict requirements, the general
guidelines suggest that a prospective
counselor be a Homewood graduate
with a bachelor's degree. Recent
graduates are particularly sought by the
committee in hopes that "their young
image will enable the applicants to
better identify with them.
In another area of the recruiting
process. the Undergraduate Admissions
Council has received the support of the
Admissions Office for its plans to help
counsel prospective applicants. The
Council was formed last year to allow
Homewood undergraduates to contact
interested high school students, in an
attempt to give them a fuller picture of
university life. Plans will be announced
later this year for the selection of
Council Aides who will meet with the
prospects in their home towns over the
Christmas recess.
No Status
The Admissions Council was created
last fall by the Student Council. At that
time the plan called for the Council to
operate as an official part of the Office
of Admissions.
The Admissions Office, however, will
grant the Council neither official nor
semi-official status (they must operate,
stated Anderson, as "interested
individuals"). Yet the Office has
welcomed their support and will in fact
ask them to contact a number of the
University's prime prospects.
According to Assistant Director
Anderson, the lack of status is a matter
of "ethics and confidentiality." High
and prep school guidance councelors are
extremely sensitive in the area of
extending confidential information to
non-staff members. Thus while
undergraduates are in an excellent
position to help with recruiting, the
judgement functions must be left to
qualified staff members.

is the incredible potency of minute doses."

By DAVID MELAMED
When LSD is used under controlled
conditions, Dr. Stanislav Graf told the freshman
class, it can lead to religious experience, artistic
creation, and an unfolding of the collective
unconscious.
Speaking before a drug seminar held at Turner Hall
last Friday, Dr. Graf outlined the history, nature, and
therapeutic uses of LSD, which he termed "the most
powerful tool of modern psychology." Dr. Graf,
Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at the University of
Maryland, has worked with hallucinogenic drugs for 12
years, and has taken LSD himself.
Dr. Graf described LSD as "an unspecific amplifier
which brings out and intensifies what is in the psyche
already. There are no symptoms which always occur in
LSD sessions." Thus, he asserted, few of the bad things
said about LSD relate to LSD itself.
Rather, Dr. Graf explained, the bad things relate to
the context in which LSD is taken. When LSD is taken
under uncontrolled conditions, several factors can create
a serious risk. The user is uncertain about the
pharmaceutalogical content of his dose, paranoid about
the possibility of being arrested, and may feel guilty
about taking LSD in the first place.
A great sensation in the scientific world was caused
when LSD was first introduced for therapeutic purposes
in the 1950's. Dr. Graf delineated two therapeutic
methods of utilitzing LSD, and showed several paintings
drawn by his patients during periods of deep ecstasy and
agony, to illustrate states of mind attained through LSD
use.
In the "psychedelic method," sessions are structured
so the subject will receive a deep mystical experience.
Before the session a doctor goes through the patient's
history in order to give the patient some idea of how his
symptoms are related to his problems. The psychedelic
method is most commonly used with alcoholics to aid
them in developing will power. It is also used to help
terminal cancer patients reconcile themselves with death.
Dr. Graf described the "psycholytic method" as an
"intensification of psychoanalysis" where LSD aids the
patient in transcending himself in -order to understand
and deal with his problems. As in psychoanalysis, the
analyst attempts to enter into the patient's world. ,
Dr. Graf stressed that drugs have existed in nearly all
cultures throughout the ages. Hashish has been widely
used throughout the Orient. In Mexico, the home
country of hallucinogenics, peyote, morning - glory seeds
and sacred mushrooms have been widely used. "What is
sensational about LSD," stated Dr. Graf, "is the
incredible potency of minute closets."
Dr. Graf suggested that the long term result of
marijuana use is "very similar to what you see with
repeated use of LSD. People start losing their drive for
achievement and begin to place much more emphasis on
joy, pleasure, and doing things for their own sake."
LSD was first discovered in Switzerland thirty years
ago during gynecological research. At this time it was
classified as an uninteresting drug not meriting further
research. Five years late, during an experiment in
Switzerland designed to find a cure for migrain
headaches, Dr. Hoffman of the Sandos Laboratory
experienced accidental intoxication from LSD. Hoffman
later discovered the cause of his experiences and
introduced LSD to the scientific world.

By PRINCE NAMOR
Cream disintegrated last November, its three members
having become very popular and very rich. Their demise
was followed by an album called
"Goodbye" — interesting in some spots but generally
very disappointing.
So "Wheels of Fire", released a year ago this summer,
was the last new music that Eric Clapton put out until
the Blind Faith album.
In an atmosphere of skillful advance publicity and
reverence for Cream (British rock magazines are still
asking, "Who'll fill the gap left by Cream's break-up?"),
Blind Faith with Eric Clapton, Ginger Baker and Steve
Winwood in the same band, was eagerly anticipated as
the first of the supergroups.
But alas, friends, a supergroup in name only. First
came their disappointing premier performance in Hyde
Park in London, then the fiasco of their American
concert tour. So everyone waited for the record. They
gotta be better on record. To make the situation worse,
the album release date was 'postponed from June 22
until the beginning of August. ATCO Records should
have postponed it indefinitely.
Racked Voice
My dissatisfaction with the Blind Faith album is
caused mainly by the ubiquitous presence of Steve
Winwood. He must be credited with "Can't Find My
Way Home", the best song on the album, but his other
tunes, "Had to Cry Today" and "Sea of Joy", are
reminiscent of his late songs for Traffic: long,
uneventful, and soporific.
Windood's singing also causes problems. Many people
can tolerate/enjoy his thin high-pitched vocals, in which
it seems he stretches his voice to the breaking point. I
can't. And in the Hyde Park concert Winwood's voice

cracked so often that the situation soon passed from
embarrasing to annoying. Definitely not a Jack Bruce.
Some of the blame for this uninteresting album must
be placed on the other musicians. Ginger Baker
continues to bang and thrash away, straining under the
belief that he has not yet impressed upon us his celerity
and agility. Okay Ginger, we're impressed. And the
puerile lyrics to his interminable song (which isn't even a
song) need not be criticized here.
Routine Playing
Clapton is the saddest tragedy of the album. His
acoustic fingering on "Can't Find My Way Home" is
excellent, as is his solo in "Presence of the Lord," an
instrumental that slides from violence to tranquility and
has almost no connection with the rest of the song. An
explanation for this disjunction can perhaps be found in
the song's lyrics (by Clapton), but this seems to be
atrributing more mental resourcefulness to Clapton than
he has otherwise demonstrated. The remainder of his
playing is very unexciting and routine, with no
advancement at all in the last year. He has yet to surpass
some of his solos on "Fresh Cream,", an album now
three years old.
And as for Rick Grech. His bass solo in "Do What
You Like" is perhaps the most unimaginative and boring
piece of music to be published anywhere in a long time.
Again, he is definitely not a Jack Bruce.
If you were disappointed with the Blind Faith album,
at least you knew who were going to perform the songs.
Not so in the case of "Truly Fine Citizen," the latest
release by Moby Grape, a once great San Francisco
group whose record "Wow" still ranks as a marvelous
and enjoyable head album. The back jacket of "Truly
Fine Citizen" consists of individual photographs of the
four members of the band, three of them easily

recognizable and the fourth with his back to the viewer,
anonymous.
Only upon opening the record and listening to it (i.e.
after putting down the shekels) do we discover the
deception we have fallen victim to. Bob Mosley, a
competent song-writer and the Grape's bassist and lead
vocalist, has gone away, to be inadequately replaced by
the mystery man on the back of the cover.
So what are we left with? A mediocre album of
country-rock on which one song is indistinguishable
from the next (mystery man wrote most of the songs.)
Some 44 executives at Columbia Records are laughing at
how simple it is to bilk ignorant record buyers. Caveat
emptor etc. etc.
No Cello
The magazines may as well continue searching tor a
replacement for Cream; the vacuum is still a vacuum.
Moby Grape has traded talent and honesty for an
unidentified bgiF player. The scene looks bad, but not
desolate. Jack Bruce has an album,"Songs for a Tailor",
to be released in November. It is supposed to be jazz,
with no cello playing. And he is preparing another
record with guitarist Larry Coryell. Then there is the
very talented anthology of Crosby, Stills, Nash and
Young.

whose second album, "Stand Up", is a definite
improvement over the first. Ian Anderson's flute work is

Cleveland's Out; Let's Push Parker
By ED MENDELSOHN
One of the most perplexing facts
of American history is the fact that
the Democratic candidate for
President in 1904 was Alton Brooks
Parker. In no other case can it be said
with such certainty that if the man
had lost the nomination he would
now be entirely unknown. There is a
traditional facile explanation of the
nomination which at least accounts
for the superficial procedures.
William Jennings Bryan had lost
stature in the party after his defeat
of 1900 which was more severe than
his loss in 1896. The right to name
the party nominee thereupon
reverted to the right wing of the
Democ- atic party, which had chosen
and continued to respect former
President Grover Cleveland.
Early in 1904 the 67-year-old Mr.
Cleveland declined to be considered
for the nomination. The Eastern
party organizations thereupon swung
behind Mr. Cleveland's choice.
Justice Parker. Mr. Parker had been
elected Chief Justice of the New
York State Court of Appeals in
1897, when the Democrats were
singularly weak in New York, and
was the only Democrat to carry the
state since Mr. Cleveland's re-election
as President in 1892.
Not Bitterly Contested
Faced with this adequate
explanation, it is still difficult to
accept a major party nomination of a
man whose opinions on major issues
and personality was unknown to the
vast majority of Americans, and even
to many of those insidehis state.
Justice Parker had spent most of his
political career on the bench, and so
had not been in a position to express
himself on contemporary issues.
Parker admittedly won a
statewide election in 1897, but a
judicial election is not normally
contested as bitterly as a campaign
for Governor, in which any candidate

must express himself on major issues.
In fact, he had been declining almost
biennially to be the gubernatorial
candidate. Had he been Governor, he
would have been a far stronger
candidate for President.
Personal Ambition
To be sure, something of Justice
Parker's opinions may be gathered
from his judicial decisions, in which
he seemed to favor labor unions, and
from an analysis of his associates.
Justice Parker was a former campaign
manager for New York Senator
David B. Hill, and much was inferred
from his support from Mr. Cleveland.
Hill had in fact opposed the
Cleveland renomination of 1892,
chiefly due to personal ambition and
a desire to build up his own wing of
the party; Cleveland and Hill were
not sufficiently far apart to disagree
on the proposition that a leader had
to be found to succeed Mr. Bryan.
Both Cleveland and Hill had more
followers than Parker, and neither
was unambitious, but each was too
old to be a viable candidate.
Moreover, each had so manifested
their convictions as to be anathema
to the Bryan wing of the party. Not
enough was known about Parker to
inspire anyone's enmity.
Sane Candidate
Another factor recommending Mr.
Parker was his position as a "good,
gray" judge in the circumstances of
this election. The Republicans had a
prohibitively strong candidate in
President Theodore Roosevelt. As
matters stood the election would be
a referendum for or against
Roosevelt, and while the President
obviously had achieved a popularity
equaling idolatry among certain
voters, any personality so strong and
abrasive is certain to acquire several
voluble enemies.
Certain Presidential remarks,
although few Presidential elections,
had upset the business community,
and the Democrats were hopeful that
a "safe and sane" candidate L.ould

gain Wail Street support against
Roosevelt. That Justice Parker had
rendered decisions comforting to
labor organization was far less known
than the fact that his principal
sponsor, former President Cleveland,
had forcibly intervened against labor
in the Pullman strike of 1894.
The very lack of forcefulness in
the Justice's personality also
improved his standing as a potential
candidate against Roosevelt. It did
appear conceivable that, in a
referendum against Roosevelt, there
would be a large negative vote. If the
Democrats had nominated a forceful
personality of their own, such as
Cleveland or William Randolph
Hearst, he himself would have
alienated many voters. Parker was
not sufficiently well-known to
alienate a voter who was prejudiced
against Roosevelt. He was therefore
potentially a fair candidate if, like
many Democrats, one accepts the
proposition that the anti-Roosevelt
vote would be very large.
Frightful Attrition
Still, to say that Parker might
receive votes because he appeared
safe, sane, and coldly judicial is to
corroborate, rather than to deny,
that, to most of the American
people, he was a vague personality
and an unknown quantity. The best
sin" explanation for Parker's
nomination is that the Democratic
party was singularly weak. This was
partially the fault of Bryan. Since he
had become identified with the
party, the Democrats had suffered
frightful attrition in the large Eastern
states which normally produced their
presidential candidates.
Parker had recently won a
statewide election, and this alone put
him in the front rank of Eastern
Democrats. When Bryan tried to
think of an Easterner whom he might
more cheerfully support, he could
make no better suggestion than
former Governor Pattison of
Pennsylvania, who had recently been

defeated for re-election.
Chicago Unpleasant
As Bryan and Cleveland did not
choose to run, none of .the figures
who contested Parker's nomination
was more magnetic. Delaware offered
former Senator George Gray. Like
Parker, Gray was a colorless and
righteous judge; unlike Parker, he
had never won an election in a
pivotal state. Most of the Bryan
following preferred publisher Hearst,
although there was no evidence he
could be elected to any office. Hearst
had been seeking the nomination far
more assiduously than Parker; at one
point, the Democractic National
Committee was so concerned for
Hearst's strength as to shift the
National Convention from Chicago,
where he appeared strong. But when
the Convention actually assembled in
St. Louis, Hearst had unimpressive
support. There were objections that
the Democrats owed a Convention to
Chicago; but after the unpleasantness
of 1968, it will probably be
conceded that the Democrats have
assembled in Chicago once too often.
Bryan himself had kind words for
Hearst, but chose to support Senator
Francis Cockrell of Missouri.
In Congress the Democrats had
some articulate spokesman who were
at least as well qualified for the
Presidency as Parker. But the
Democratic spokesmen were usually
Southerners. They were therefore
out of consideration for the
nomination, as their own region was
expected to vote Democratic
regardless of the nominee, and they
would have had difficulty generating
further support in the North.
Thus, largely for want of a viable
alternative, and not lacking in the
optimism
which
normally
charm...ten/es National Conventions,
the Democrats gave their standard to
Justice Parker. In my next coluinn I
shall describe the Justice's surprising
reaction.

Science fiction? The troubled dreams of an

The computerized library will be made possible by

delivered the talk yesterday.
A large time-sharing computer system would allow as
many as 2000 users to communicate via teletype with
one or more large high speed digital computers
simultaneously. The machine switches back and forth
between the various users so rapidly that each one has
the illusion that he has the computer all to himself. The
service could cost as little as two dollars an hour.
Time Sharing Advantages
The great advantage of computer time-sharing is that
it allows the user to hold "conversations" with the
computer. Instead of waiting hours for the results to
come back from the computing center, answers to
questions or other information are received within
seconds.
The rapidly diminishing cost of time-sharing facilities
will permit a "computer in every home," Dr. Kemeny
explained. The harried housewife will be able to do
comparative shopping from a terminal in her own
kitchen, and aspiring but inexperienced quarterbacks
will be able to play totally realistic football games
against an opponent anywhere in the world, with the
computer acting as football, field, and referee.

existence are vast. According to Dr. Kemeny, a large
time-sharing system could handle the registration of jobs
and match employee criteria against existing openings.
Other systems could have similar uses in housing, law
enforcement, traffic control, education, and medical
diagnosis. While computers have done much to improve
efficiency and reduce cost, "little or no effort has been
expended to try to think up new services, made possible
by the high speed computer, to make life better for most
of us. This may be one of the significant reasons why the
man on the street feels resentment towards computers."

of our civilization, by facilitating the decentralization of
our way of life. If business can be conducted by means
of computers - - allowing instant communication and
data recording and retrieving on a world-wide

basis - - modern man will not have to infest large urb
sprawls, now the breeding ground for most social ills.

economy and the resulting revenue for the Feder

Finally, because the research and developme

the means of any local or state government and may r
be profitable enough to attract the attention

By PRINCE NAMOR
Cream disintegrated last November, its three members
having become very popular and very rich. Their demise
was followed by an album called
"Goodbye" — interesting in some spots but generally
very disappointing.
So "Wheels of Fire", released a year ago this summer,
was the last new music that Eric Clapton put out until
the Blind Faith album.
In an atmosphere of skillful advance publicity and
reverence for Cream (British rock magazines are still
asking, "Who'll fill the gap left by Cream's break-up?"),
Blind Faith with Eric Clapton, Ginger Baker and Steve
Winwood in the same band, was eagerly anticipated as
the first of the supergroups.
But alas, friends, a supergroup in name only. First
came their disappointing premier performance in Hyde
Park in London, then the fiasco of their American
concert tour. So everyone waited for the record. They
gotta be better on record. To make the situation worse,
the album release date was 'postponed from June 22
until the beginning of August. ATCO Records should
have postponed it indefinitely.
Racked Voice
My dissatisfaction with the Blind Faith album is
caused mainly by the ubiquitous presence of Steve
Winwood. He must be credited with "Can't Find My
Way Home", the best song on the album, but his other
tunes, "Had to Cry Today" and "Sea of Joy", are
reminiscent of his late songs for Traffic: long,
uneventful, and soporific.
Windood's singing also causes problems. Many people
can tolerate/enjoy his thin high-pitched vocals, in which
it seems he stretches his voice to the breaking point. I
can't. And in the Hyde Park concert Winwood's voice

cracked so often that the situation soon passed from
embarrasing to annoying. Definitely not a Jack Bruce.
Some of the blame for this uninteresting album must
be placed on the other musicians. Ginger Baker
continues to bang and thrash away, straining under the
belief that he has not yet impressed upon us his celerity
and agility. Okay Ginger, we're impressed. And the
puerile lyrics to his interminable song (which isn't even a
song) need not be criticized here.
Routine Playing
Clapton is the saddest tragedy of the album. His
acoustic fingering on "Can't Find My Way Home" is
excellent, as is his solo in "Presence of the Lord," an
instrumental that slides from violence to tranquility and
has almost no connection with the rest of the song. An
explanation for this disjunction can perhaps be found in
the song's lyrics (by Clapton), but this seems to be
atrributing more mental resourcefulness to Clapton than
he has otherwise demonstrated. The remainder of his
playing is very unexciting and routine, with no
advancement at all in the last year. He has yet to surpass
some of his solos on "Fresh Cream,", an album now
three years old.
And as for Rick Grech. His bass solo in "Do What
You Like" is perhaps the most unimaginative and boring
piece of music to be published anywhere in a long time.
Again, he is definitely not a Jack Bruce.
If you were disappointed with the Blind Faith album,
at least you knew who were going to perform the songs.
Not so in the case of "Truly Fine Citizen," the latest
release by Moby Grape, a once great San Francisco
group whose record "Wow" still ranks as a marvelous
and enjoyable head album. The back jacket of "Truly
Fine Citizen" consists of individual photographs of the
four members of the band, three of them easily

recognizable and the fourth with his back to the viewer,
anonymous.
Only upon opening the record and listening to it (i.e.
after putting down the shekels) do we discover the
deception we have fallen victim to. Bob Mosley, a
competent song-writer and the Grape's bassist and lead
vocalist, has gone away, to be inadequately replaced by
the mystery man on the back of the cover.
So what are we left with? A mediocre album of
country-rock on which one song is indistinguishable
from the next (mystery man wrote most of the songs.)
Some 44 executives at Columbia Records are laughing at
how simple it is to bilk ignorant record buyers. Caveat
emptor etc. etc.
No Cello

replacement for Cream; the vacuum is still a vacuum.

unidentified bgiF player. The scene looks bad, but not
desolate. Jack Bruce has an album,"Songs for a Tailor",

with no cello playing. And he is preparing another
record with guitarist Larry Coryell. Then there is the
very talented anthology of Crosby, Stills, Nash and

improvement over the first. Ian Anderson's flute work is

has left to form Bloodwyn Pig, a blues band. His

makes Jethro Tull and "Stand Up" a successful one-mat
show.

Cleveland's Out; Let's Push Parker
By ED MENDELSOHN
One of the most perplexing facts
of American history is the fact that
the Democratic candidate for
President in 1904 was Alton Brooks
Parker. In no other case can it be said
with such certainty that if the man
had lost the nomination he would
now be entirely unknown. There is a
traditional facile explanation of the
nomination which at least accounts
for the superficial procedures.
William Jennings Bryan had lost
stature in the party after his defeat
of 1900 which was more severe than
his loss in 1896. The right to name
the party nominee thereupon
reverted to the right wing of the
Democ- atic party, which had chosen
and continued to respect former
President Grover Cleveland.
Early in 1904 the 67-year-old Mr.
Cleveland declined to be considered
for the nomination. The Eastern
party organizations thereupon swung
behind Mr. Cleveland's choice.
Justice Parker. Mr. Parker had been
elected Chief Justice of the New
York State Court of Appeals in
1897, when the Democrats were
singularly weak in New York, and
was the only Democrat to carry the
state since Mr. Cleveland's re-election
as President in 1892.
Not Bitterly Contested
Faced with this adequate
explanation, it is still difficult to
accept a major party nomination of a
man whose opinions on major issues
and personality was unknown to the
vast majority of Americans, and even
to many of those insidehis state.
Justice Parker had spent most of his
political career on the bench, and so
had not been in a position to express
himself on contemporary issues.
Parker admittedly won a
statewide election in 1897, but a
judicial election is not normally
contested as bitterly as a campaign
for Governor, in which any candidate

must express himself on major issues.
In fact, he had been declining almost
biennially to be the gubernatorial
candidate. Had he been Governor, he
would have been a far stronger
candidate for President.
Personal Ambition
To be sure, something of Justice
Parker's opinions may be gathered
from his judicial decisions, in which
he seemed to favor labor unions, and
from an analysis of his associates.
Justice Parker was a former campaign
manager for New York Senator
David B. Hill, and much was inferred
from his support from Mr. Cleveland.
Hill had in fact opposed the
Cleveland renomination of 1892,
chiefly due to personal ambition and
a desire to build up his own wing of
the party; Cleveland and Hill were
not sufficiently far apart to disagree
on the proposition that a leader had
to be found to succeed Mr. Bryan.
Both Cleveland and Hill had more
followers than Parker, and neither
was unambitious, but each was too
old to be a viable candidate.
Moreover, each had so manifested
their convictions as to be anathema
to the Bryan wing of the party. Not
enough was known about Parker to
inspire anyone's enmity.
Sane Candidate
Another factor recommending Mr.
Parker was his position as a "good,
gray" judge in the circumstances of
this election. The Republicans had a
prohibitively strong candidate in
President Theodore Roosevelt. As
matters stood the election would be
a referendum for or against
Roosevelt, and while the President
obviously had achieved a popularity
equaling idolatry among certain
voters, any personality so strong and
abrasive is certain to acquire several
voluble enemies.
Certain Presidential remarks,
although few Presidential elections,
had upset the business community,
and the Democrats were hopeful that
a "safe and sane" candidate L.ould

gain Wail Street support against
Roosevelt. That Justice Parker had
rendered decisions comforting to
labor organization was far less known
than the fact that his principal
sponsor, former President Cleveland,
had forcibly intervened against labor
in the Pullman strike of 1894.
The very lack of forcefulness in
the Justice's personality also
improved his standing as a potential
candidate against Roosevelt. It did
appear conceivable that, in a
referendum against Roosevelt, there
would be a large negative vote. If the
Democrats had nominated a forceful
personality of their own, such as
Cleveland or William Randolph
Hearst, he himself would have
alienated many voters. Parker was
not sufficiently well-known to
alienate a voter who was prejudiced
against Roosevelt. He was therefore
potentially a fair candidate if, like
many Democrats, one accepts the
proposition that the anti-Roosevelt
vote would be very large.
Frightful Attrition
Still, to say that Parker might
receive votes because he appeared
safe, sane, and coldly judicial is to
corroborate, rather than to deny,
that, to most of the American
people, he was a vague personality
and an unknown quantity. The best
sin" explanation for Parker's
nomination is that the Democratic
party was singularly weak. This was
partially the fault of Bryan. Since he
had become identified with the
party, the Democrats had suffered
frightful attrition in the large Eastern
states which normally produced their
presidential candidates.
Parker had recently won a
statewide election, and this alone put
him in the front rank of Eastern
Democrats. When Bryan tried to
think of an Easterner whom he might
more cheerfully support, he could
make no better suggestion than
former Governor Pattison of
Pennsylvania, who had recently been

defeated for re-election.
Chicago Unpleasant
As Bryan and Cleveland did not
choose to run, none of .the figures
who contested Parker's nomination
was more magnetic. Delaware offered
former Senator George Gray. Like
Parker, Gray was a colorless and
righteous judge; unlike Parker, he
had never won an election in a
pivotal state. Most of the Bryan
following preferred publisher Hearst,
although there was no evidence he
could be elected to any office. Hearst
had been seeking the nomination far
more assiduously than Parker; at one
point, the Democractic National
Committee was so concerned for
Hearst's strength as to shift the
National Convention from Chicago,
where he appeared strong. But when
the Convention actually assembled in
St. Louis, Hearst had unimpressive
support. There were objections that
the Democrats owed a Convention to
Chicago; but after the unpleasantness
of 1968, it will probably be
conceded that the Democrats have
assembled in Chicago once too often.
Bryan himself had kind words for
Hearst, but chose to support Senator
Francis Cockrell of Missouri.
In Congress the Democrats had
some articulate spokesman who were
at least as well qualified for the
Presidency as Parker. But the
Democratic spokesmen were usually
Southerners. They were therefore
out of consideration for the
nomination, as their own region was
expected to vote Democratic
regardless of the nominee, and they
would have had difficulty generating
further support in the North.
Thus, largely for want of a viable
alternative, and not lacking in the
optimism
which
normally
charm...ten/es National Conventions,
the Democrats gave their standard to
Justice Parker. In my next coluinn I
shall describe the Justice's surprising
reaction.
